TopicTitle: Why are conspiracy sites so common for space searches on google images

Articles.Content:
After the general wikipedia and wikimedia commons things show up, and maybe nasa.gov, then half of the images sources are from MOONLANDINGREEE.com.  This doesn't happen for the general searches, only for images.

EDIT: This seems to happen more with more obscure space subjects or uh... shall we say controversial scientists or engineers.  Tin-foil hat maniacs love von braun for some reason.  I was doing an infographic and essay on von braun so I saw lots about how "NASA IS EVILLL VON BRAUN REEEEEEEE".  It's kinda weird how half the same people who say that nasa is evil because of von braun are also holocaust denialists, which is rather contradictory (But lets not talk about that because then my thread will catch on fire).

Edited March 15, 2017 by Rath
Because idiots like looking at pictures more than they like reading?
I notice a similar thing with youtube - watch an astronomy-related video and if left to automatically start the next "related video", pretty soon it's playing flat earth and gophers on mars.

Why are sites about space games are so much more common than sites about repairing of fans and pumps in zero gravity?

'cuz space is phun!
Everybody looks for his own kind of entertainment and mostly nobody except nerds is entertained a lot by space mechanics (in both senses of "mechanics").

Edited March 15, 2017 by kerbiloid

I haven't noticed it. I've never even heard of the site you speak of.

That's why I went to google and searched "moon", "moon landing", "iss", "jupiter" and "geostationary satellite". I skimmed a few pages for each search and not a single result from the site you mention; I've noticed only one from flat Earth society on the last query.

It must be your search and browsing history. Just admit it, you're a closet foil hatter.
This treacherous google adaptive search... Ranks the links according to user's habits.

Use a different search engine ...

Suggestion: block these tagging and filtering sites like google, facebook, youtube, .... completely from your pc/network. The internet will become much clearer, pages load faster and information less narrowed ;-)

Is this paranoid ? I don't think so ...

:-)
And miss the Nibiru arrival? No way.

I'm gonna miss it. But i don't miss it :-)

 

 

Edit: But this isn't really science or spaceflight, or is it ? Should it be moved to the Lounge ?

 

Edited March 15, 2017 by Green Baron

Perhaps.  But this is still about spaceflight while the lounge is fully off-topic.

 

And, it's social science and the signals go through satellites so we can view it!/s

I've occasionally noticed a result taking me to a conspiracy page, but not really as a general trend.  However, because they like to zoom in and examine the tiniest of details, those sites are sometimes good sources of large, hi-res images.  I got a few of the wallpapers on my laptop from a moon landing hoax site.

I would have had you not already done so. 90% of my searches are accomplished by Duckduckgo.

I use this, primarily when the connections aren't crappy (when it does, I gave up and just use google - too often much faster, but god knows how many data they are having !)

You can try this one. Yes most of it will be basic, but after that you'll see the "standard" scientific sites - I'm not sure, but probably after tens of pages you'd start getting arXiv ?

Yes I realize most of this is in YouTube and most can be considered polarized, but if you took the contents neutrally you can see that at least, YouTube content spread grows out of proper engagement - you have, have to see what's inside (unless you're a hard tinfoil or smh - I believe the reverse doesn't work), unlike some other platforms where the headline is enough.

 

EDIT : I have to admit apparently few tinfoil suggestions did make it for some of these videos, but that just shows that YouTube doesn't nitpick who can come. Though then you'd have to nitpick them yourself.
